description.plain:
Jason “Jadakiss” Phillips is a successful millionaire hip-hop sensation, who remained in the spotlight for many decades after his debut. Jadakiss lived most of his childhood in Yonkers, New York.

Jadakiss started selling drugs at the age of 12 when his parents told him that he should start making money on his own. One day, Jadakiss noticed people freestyling on the streets. He became curious and took part in it, later realizing that this could be the source of a future career prospect. Jada took it further and entered competitions leaving the drug trade. While rapping on the streets, Jada met DMX who later introduced him to his future lifelong friends Sheek Louch and Styles P.

The three later went on to form a rap group called “The Warlocks” which is known today as “The LOX” – an acronym for “Living Off X-perience.” Jadakiss’ group released their first album in 1994 called Fuck What You Think which became a major catalyst for his career. From the age of 16, Jadakiss was known throughout the hip-hop community as a successful freestyle rapper who made approximately $707,000 annually.

Jadakiss continues to release albums on his own as a solo artist to further prove that he is one of the greatest rappers alive. During the 80s and 90s, Jadakiss learned with other artists in the industry by listening to their music Jadakiss listened to B.I.G, 2Pac, The Alchemist, Snoop Dogg, and R. Kelly. Jadakiss also learned marketing and business practices which landed him a contract deal with Bad Boy Entertainment.

That ain't get that break?
Why you don't stack instead of tryin' to be fly?

songs.full_title: We Gonna Make It by Jadakiss (Ft. Styles P)
songs.title: We Gonna Make It
songs.title_with_featured: We Gonna Make It (Ft. Styles P)

description.plain:
“We Gonna Make It” was released as a single from Jada’s debut solo album Kiss tha Game Goodbye and featured a back-and-forth with his LOX teammate Styles P. The Alchemist sampled a section of Samuel Jonathan Johnson’s 1978 track “My Music” for the beat, which was involved in some controversy.

Al shopped the beat to different artists, claiming a deal with Nas fell through before his publicized issue around only getting half the money from a deal with Ras Kass, who used the beat for his track “Home Sweet Home” before “We Gonna Make It” came out. The single peaked at #5 on the Billboard Hot Rap Songs chart and the remix for “We Gonna Make It” featured fellow Ruff Ryder Eve.

songs.full_title: By Your Side by Jadakiss
songs.title: By Your Side

description.plain:
Hot track from Jada’s sophomore album Kiss of Death, released in 2004 on Ruff Ryders/Interscope

Jadakiss deftly weaves his rap around the “by your side” sample, stopping his rap to allow the sample to finish his rhyme. The lyrics are formatted around this sample so that it flows nicely

This song takes the form of an ode. It is challenging at times to decipher who or what Jadakiss is speaking to. It mostly seems like he is talking to the listener, the fan. At times it also sounds like he is talking to a close friend and some lines seems as if he is talking to his gun. Although the song is called “By Your Side” a lot of the imagery is that of loneliness, loss, and absence

songs.title: Welcome to D-Block
songs.title_with_featured: Welcome to D-Block (Ft. Eminem, Sheek Louch & Styles P)

description.plain:
Jadakiss, Styles P, and Sheek Louch, the 3 members of The Lox, often shout out D-Block on their songs.  It’s what they call their neighborhood in Yonkers.  The term may have been coined as a reference to the maximum security wing at Alcatraz, but regardless of it’s origin, The Lox have turned D-Block into a catch-all term for a rough and scary neighborhood

Eminem drops one of his best verses in a guest-spot and gets all sing-songy on the chorus

annotatable.title: Welcome to D-Block

body.plain:
Jadakiss, Styles P, and Sheek Louch, the 3 members of The Lox, often shout out D-Block on their songs.  It’s what they call their neighborhood in Yonkers.  The term may have been coined as a reference to the maximum security wing at Alcatraz, but regardless of it’s origin, The Lox have turned D-Block into a catch-all term for a rough and scary neighborhood

Eminem drops one of his best verses in a guest-spot and gets all sing-songy on the chorus

songs.full_title: Letter to B.I.G. by Jadakiss (Ft. Faith Evans)
songs.title: Letter to B.I.G.

description.plain:
A Tribute song of rapper Jadakiss to his late friend, rap legend Notorious B.I.G.

The song was composed for B.I.G.’s biopic film “Notorious” (released in 2009), the chorus is sung by Biggie’s widow, popular singer Faith Evans

songs.full_title: Still Feel Me by Jadakiss
songs.title: Still Feel Me

description.plain:
After working on “Feel Me” from Jada’s 2001 debut solo album Kiss tha Game Goodbye, Jadakiss and The Alchemist reconnect for “Still Feel Me.” Al gave his take on the “Feel Me” series to Complex:

It was interesting because we had ‘Feel Me’ and he wanted you to still feel him. I guess he had feel issues. You felt him on feel me, but then he wanted you to still feel him. So shout out to Jadakiss for really demanding that you feel his shit. Pause. Infinite Pause.

While both songs sample a sound effect from “In the Rain” by The Dramatics, this version is based around a sample from Nick Sargent’s 1985 electronic track “New Life”:

https://youtu.be/IKKoCpgfObw?t=48

[Jadakiss]
What if the pain went away?

What if you could eliminate all the games people played?
What if Shyne beat the case?
What if Diddy did a dime flat?

Carhartt to match it, unlaced Timbs

songs.full_title: Put Your Hands Up by Jadakiss
songs.title: Put Your Hands Up

description.plain:
Released in 2001, this is one of Jadakiss' most popular singles and represents the attitude of his solo album “Kiss Tha Game Goodbye.”

“Put Ya Hands Up” is about Jadakiss lyrically distinguishing himself from his hip-hop peers while demonstrating his ability to “hype a crowd.”

The song was also a poke at Beanie Seigal who was on the Jay-Z track Do It Again (Put Ya Hands Up) as Jada is telling the crowd “Nah, fuck that put ya hands down”

songs.full_title: Jason by Jadakiss (Ft. Swizz Beatz)
songs.title: Jason

description.plain: In this track Jadakiss speaks out against the highly publicized police shootings of black men in America. Jadakiss uses “I can’t breath” over his beat throughout the track. This is a reference to Eric Garner who was choked to death by New York police in 2014. Jadakiss' intent with this song is to highlight the experience of minority groups within the ghetto and show the hostile relationship between himself (and his community) and the police. The music video helps to illuminate many of the themes present in the lyrics, it is suggested that they are experienced together.

songs.title: Ice Pick

description.plain:
Kiss dedicates this solo song to his friend and Ruff Ryders A&R Jay “Icepick” Jackson.

Pick passed away in June 2017 after a battle with cancer. He left a lasting impression on the hip-hop world and was credited as executive producer on all of Jadakiss' solo albums as well as projects from DMX and Eve.
